content.description: the whole run fingers to thin hands OW fist's squeeze roof jam's stemming all of it
content.protection: 1.5-#6 camlot double on the #3 camlots
content.location: 50 yds right of Critic's choice

content.description: Great warm up on the right side of the cliff. Starts in a flare. Thin hands quickly leads to perfect hands and some wide hands over small roofs. Flare goes to left facing corner before the anchors. A bit sandy but overall very good route on great rock.
content.protection: 1 #1, 6 #2, 2 #3 Camalots
content.location: 5-10 minutes past Second Choice.

content.description: Varying sizes with a punch at the end that can be done a couple ways.
content.protection:
.5 to 5 - latest book says “optional 5”. I’d suggest taking it.

Rings at the top.
content.location: On the same ledge and left of Acronymph

content.description: A wonderful right-facing corner. Starts thin, works through a flare, pulls a cool roof, and then finishes with some fun wide climbing.
content.protection: Doubles .75-5 camalot
content.location: Left of Second Choice in a right-facing corner formed by the pillar of Just Because.

content.description: A fun squeeze chimney if you set up a top rope by lowering to the anchor from BBC of Cleveland and climb from the right. A scary offwidth/chimney lead if you try to use the bolts on the left side. The start is too tight to fit inside easily on the left, and the second bolt is really high above the first.
content.protection: 3 bolts
content.location: The chimney between critics choice and BBC of cleveland.

content.description: fingers in a dihedral leads to a few face moves to gain a seam with a rest, then fire a short section of 0.5 crack to an easier but slightly sandy traverse to the chains. Not in my guidebook, anyone have FA info?
content.protection: doubles metolius 00 thru BD 0.5, with extra purple metolius (I had 2 and would have been happier with 3-4 to sew it up). 1x BD 0.75-3 for the easy last section. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Starts in obvious small right facing dihedral just around the corner left of Ruby Flame, then follows a right arching crack to the chains.

content.description: Ascend a crumbly off width or start on Knees without Honor to gain the large flake. Jam to the top and pull some spicy exit moves. A short distance above the flake is the anchors. You wont be able to see the anchors from the ground.
content.protection: Heavy on 2s and 3s. Maybe a 4.
content.location: Starts on Knees without Honor or the crumbly tower to sandwiched between Short and Stout and Knees without Honor.

content.description: Starts out with easy hands and then widens out for the crux. Rest up at the bottom of the chimney before the last 10' to the top.
content.protection: 4's and 5's. Some small gear for the bottom. Bolted anchor.
content.location: Splitter crack to the right of Ruby Flame and Critical Mass (corner).

content.description:
Tom's Thumb is a left facing corner that starts with off-fingers and quicky pinches down to tips (no purple camalot necessary). Climb through a scoop/ledge and steep changing corners that leads to easier terrain with good fingers and feet.

Looks and climbs like The Piano at Fin Wall (10+), but much easier.

11- grade on plaque, but this seems very generous.
content.protection: Blue alien to 0.75 Camalot (optional lager piece at top). Metolious Rap Hangers for anchor.
content.location: Thin LFC to the right of big ledge that Acronymph starts on. Plaque.

content.description: Get ready to loose some skin. Fingernails start in a layback corner leads to strong moves between solid finger locks. As the name implies this route is short and tipsy.
content.protection: Thin, bring your aliens.
content.location: Left most side of critics choice wall.

content.description:
Finger crack to flare to roof.

Nice black varnish.
content.protection: Small to #2, and a #5
content.location: Furthest right route at the cliff

climbs.name: Short and Stout
climbs.fa: Darron Reay and Agjohns, fall of 2015

content.description:
A sandy ramp leads to a fist splitter.  Climb that to the top of a short pillar.  Worth doing for some #4 practice.

Gets afternoon sun.
content.protection: BD: one 3 and two (new) 4's will suffice.  Bolted anchor
content.location:
Find this short little romp about 50 feet right of Brutus's prayer wheel.

The pillar is marked by some recent graffiti; someone (I would guess a climber?) scratched the words "X" and "Loose" to the right of the crack.  I didn't feel the pillar to be loose, but it could be cracked through at the base, so take care.

content.description: Fingers down to tips and stemming at the top in a left facing corner on really good varnish.
content.protection: Doubles black alien through 1 camalot
content.location: Located just right of "Cult Classic", plaqued.

content.description: Beautiful, clean, off-fingers and thin hands in an overhanging corner, roof at the top.
content.location: about one hundred feet right of Critic's Choice

content.description: Fingers to hands to fists in a left facing flake.
content.location: In between Life and Rite to Life

content.description: The guide book describes this route as twin cracks to splitter offwidth but the offwidth is flaring, not splitter.  Either way the route is fun if your into offwidths, but may be a little sandy since it doesn't get climbed much.
content.protection: #1 to #4.5 Camalots.
content.location: This route is located to the left of Bunny Slope and about 15' right of the large dihedral.  There is a two bolt anchor at the top with slings.

climbs.name: Refractory Period
climbs.fa: Ben Hamilton, Shaun Reed, and Phil Powers in ~2011

content.description: Crack on face widening gradually from fingers to short section of OW before the chains.
content.protection: BD 0.4-3, one 4-5 (or both) for the finish. bolted anchor
content.location: About 30 feet left around the corner from Ruby Flame.

content.description: Great Warm up on this side of the wall. Immediately right of 'Unnamed 5.10 flare'. Some well-protected chimney moves with an interesting step across at the top of the route when the flake ends behind you. Mostly off-fingers and tight hands.

Rattly fists in overhanging splitter crack. It is unclear whether this route is properly described in the guidebook or not.  This is the crack that was behind the route "Life" that fell off.

The guide also mentions that this rock is soft, its not.  The quality seems good, and so is the quality of the climbing.  However, this route is NOT 5.10!!! Unless you have monster sized fists.

The anchor also seems to be fine, as of Spring 2013.
content.protection: one or two each camalots in yellow and blue.  Then some new #4's, then a fistfull of the old #4's (purple).  A new #5 will work for some of this.  Take what you feel you are comfortable with for 30 feet of hard steep rattly fists.
content.location: Left end of the Critics Choice buttress proper, I think its the last route you see before hiking to "Bellyfull".

climbs.name: Mr. Critical
climbs.fa: Neil Kauffman, Trevor Bowman, Joel Kauffman, Alf  4/10/11

content.description:
A splitter, crescent-shaped OW into squeeze chimney. Quite clean, as it's been water-worn over the eons, somewhat like the Drainpipe in Donnelly.

A couple butterflies lead to stacks/kneelocks and into the crux stretch of chickenwings and heel-toeing; the squeeze gradually widens and you can fully burrow in before finishing up an unexpected handcrack on the left wall to the belay ledge. A great blue-collar trainer!
content.protection: (1)#2,old #4, new #5, new #6 Camalots, blue big bro, slings. Chain anchors.
content.location: About 5 minutes to the left of Bunny Slope. No plaque, but anchors are visible and the route will be obvious from the pictures.

content.description:
Edit: Probably don't climb this. The whole thing could come down! Not sure why I did it in the first place.

Some cool sporty moves with an arete and tips crack lead into powerful thin crack moves. More sporty movement guards the anchor, when the crack thins back down.

This crack is formed by a severely overhanging detached flake, that is no more than a few feet thick. While I was able to aid up it without incident, its hard to tell if a lead fall would rip gear and/or cause the entire route to fall down.
content.protection: 4 red C3s, 4 blue X4s
content.location: 400' right of Bellyful

content.description: Hand to fist crack, a little crumbly.
content.protection: In Oct 06' I pulled the anchor (4"x1/2" rawl, hanger stamped "Comp Wall") out by hand. The new FA (I'm assuming "life had different anchors that fell off with it, these new bad anchors were placed on the freshly exposed rock) had drilled very poorly on softer than average rock. Since that time people have been rapping off my cam and leaving a note that you'll die if you climb this. I put in a 2 bolt anchor with a little glue in March 07. Because of the softness, I don't know how long the anchor will hold up. The route takes hand to fist size cams.
content.location:
On the yellow and white horizontally striped wall to the right of Bellyfull 200yds. The two routes in the same alcove still have shit anchors.

If you read your guidebook for "Life" you will get to this route. Life is no longer there, it fell down. What remains is a surprisingly good hand to fist crack.

content.description: Climb through a thin loose section over a low ledge. Climb down behind the crack you just climbed, pull your wide gear through too you and continue back 15ft to the perfect wide crack.
content.protection: Small cames for the start plus a 1 to 3 wide cams. Two bolt anchor.
content.location: This route is a little ways right of Short and Stout.

climbs.name: Just Because
climbs.fa: Darron Reay and Agjohns, fall of 2015

content.description: This route begins with a couple of hand jams to some fun finger jams, and eventually leads to athletic climbing past a lone bolt to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Doubles to .5, single 1 and 2 for down low.  One quickdraw for the bolt.
content.location: To the left of Second Choice on a pillar/wall with a short finger crack, single bolt, and bolted anchor.

climbs.name: The Hitch Hiker's Thumb
climbs.fa: Pat Kingsbury, Trevor Bowman, Neil Kauffman, Kyler Pallister 11/10/08

content.description:
An excellent offwidth route up an aesthetic tower! Start on the downhill face, up the obvious offwidth in a left-facing dihedral which pierces the entire tower and separates the main pinnacle from the flying buttress to the left. There's a plaque beneath the route, and a summit register wedged into the loose summit blocks.

The name comes from the profile of the tower, which is thumb-like from most directions, but especially so when viewed from directly downhill with the flying buttress as the fist and the summit pinnacle as the thumb.

P1- Starts out with new #5 camalots and gradually widens to sustained squeeze (wider than tipped out #6 friend) by the top. The rock is great, with just a bit of sandy stuff as you pull over onto the belay ledge. There are two bulges, the lower being the crux and is conveniently laybacked around. A really nice pitch, even for those who aren't OW gurus. Good belay ledge. 5.11 90'

P2- A 6 bolt ladder to the three bolt summit anchor, which is a bit below the actual summit due to rock quality. The bolts are well-spaced, so aiders are nice to have. The true topout requires carefully scrambling atop some loose blocks, a bit unnerving at first glance, but we successfully perched four guys up there without mishap. A0 25'
content.protection: 1-new #5 camalot, 2-new #6 camalots, 2-#6 friends, blue big bro, aiders, jumars.
content.location:
The tower is found in the back recesses of the canyon between Critics Choice and the Prow. It's not really a part of Critics Choice, but that's the closest area.

Drive 4.8 miles up Beef Basin road from the junction with 211 (at the toilet) and turn right on a two-track. Follow this for about 1/2 mile (passable for most vehicles) until it deteriorates into a wash. Hike up the road for another 1/2 mile or so and then cut over to the hillside following washes. Slog uphill in a defined wash that has some shitrock hoodoos on the left. This should put you beneath the Thumb after about 45 minutes to an hour.

The tower is hidden against the adjacent cliff, and is very hard to discern until you're up beneath it on the approach. The route lies on the downhill face of the tower and ascends the splitter OW in a left-facing corner with a plaque beneath it.

content.description:
Pull onto a shelf, twin cracks up a pillar/ramp (good hands in left crack), then up the clean left-facing dihedral with fists, off-fists, and a few stacks. The meat of the climb is old #4 camalots, rattly fists or good butterflies.

This is a clean varied pitch, but it's pretty far out in no-man's land. There's a plaque.
content.protection:
BD sizes--(2X) #1,#2,new #4, new #5 (3-4) old #4

Chain anchors on small stance to the right of the crack under the big roof up high.
content.location: Off by itself on the far left side of the wall. About 10 minutes or so around the corner from Bunny Slope.

climbs.name: Fist of Fury
climbs.fa: Shaun Reed, Ben Hamilton, Phil Powers

content.description:
We did this route a few years ago now (2011?) and I may not have the details quite right. This route is 5 - 10 minutes to the left of Bunny Slope, around the corner. I still need to go back and put a plaque at the base, but the route has an obvious fist to OW crack roof traverse (the route's namesake) about 80 or 90 ft up that is about 10 ft long. The crack starts off the ground as fingers and slowly widens to hands before the roof, then good fists and liebacking through the roof. I think you can get by with a double rack of cams up to BD#3, then at least one #4 and #5, and probably a #6 above the lip. Crack is very clean, but we did have to pull off a 15 ft tall skinny block in the middle of the route, which is probably why nobody had done it before. The rock above the roof is a bit crumbly, but not too difficult. When I did the route, I remember my fists fit perfectly (normal size male hands) and it felt like climbing one of those peg boards we had in gym class.

Two bolt anchor at the top. I'm pretty sure a 60m rope will get you down.

Have fun!
Right of bunny slope, short hands to fingers in a slab
content.protection: tips- 3"

content.description: Hands through a roof, then offwidth and past a massive block through another roof and then splitter hands up high.  A good warm up for the zone.
content.protection: Doubles 1 through 5 with extra 1s and 2s, plus a 6 for the start.
content.location: Located just right of "Mr. Critical".  Plaqued.

content.description: Gaint wide corner to the right of Ruby Flame.
content.protection: Wide to wider. You may want a big bro..
content.location: Right of Ruby Flame

content.description: This is a super classic, super pumpy splitter.  Goes from tips with quite a few feet to pumpy good fingers, a bit of off-fingers, and then a final thirty foot sprint through STEEP perfect hands to the anchors.  Sometimes sandy, and usually unsullied by lame-ass chalk and tick marks.
content.protection: You will die if you use Bloom's gear beta of only one .5 Friend.  Friends Sizes: (4).5, (3).75, (2)1, (3)1.5, (3)2.5, (2)3
content.location: From the approach trail's topout, go a few hundred yards to the right, then look for the most classic splitter on the cliff.

content.description: Super long, low-angled perfect hands in a corner.
content.protection: 8-10 gold camalots, a few reds, maybe a blue.
content.location: from the approach trail's topout, head left, past the "Belly Full of Bad Berries" arch for a few hundred feet.

content.description: Offwidth and squeeze lead to a tunnel like section that is climbed on the outside and protected by 3 bolts, then more squeeze to the top.
content.protection: #5 camalot through blue tubes.
content.location: Right of "critics choice"

content.description: Left of Ed's world about 60 feet, you'll find a marvelous big hands to fists to offwidth crack in a right facing dihedral. In the guidebook it's listed as Blue Square (5.10), so that's what I'm posting it here as. Start between a boulder and the wall up on a pedestal and climb teacups and fists up bomber stone till you get to knees, then wings and eventually a squeezy tunnel where you can breathe the finest dust the desert has to offer. Grovel up through and enjoy the view! Well protected and a blast from bottom to top. Would be 4 stars if the anchors were placed better and the ending grovel wasn't so dirty.
content.protection: Needs a 70m to lower. Highly recommend taking around 30 feet of cord to extend the anchor to keep your rope a bit cleaner. Our rack was (2)2s, (6)3s, (1)4, 5, and a 6 will make the route as comfortable as you can make it. Don't believe the guidebook recs for a 60m rope and lots of 4s and 5s. Metolius pieces between bd 3 and 4 are great here too.
content.location: The best-looking splitter between Ed's world and bunny slope. Right facing dihedral.

content.description: 45 degree overhanging splitter offwidth.  Nuff said.
content.protection: camalot sizes: (1).75, 1, 2, 3, (2-3)4, (2)4.5, (1)5.  The old 4 camalots work way better than the new c4's.
content.location: go left from where the trail hits the cliff, head towards the obvious inset arch.

content.description:
BBC from Cleveland is a worthy crack up at the Critic's Choice.

Scramble up 15' of 5.easy choss.  Enter a 10' squeeze that protects well with hand sized cams.  Step onto the top of the pillar, breathe a second, then enter the thin hands section before switching cracks to the right and going for the anchors.
content.protection: Cams, 3-4 each, 1.5 inches to 3.5 inches (green to blue camalots.)
content.location: Critic's choice wall, between critic's choice and second choice. Plaqued.

content.description: This route climbs a thin offset crack that angles to the left.  The gear is mostly tight fingers and fingers with a couple hand pieces near the top.  An interesting route that is NOT splitter.
content.protection: .3 to 2 with extra finger sizes in the .3 and .4 range.  A couple green Aliens are nice to have down low.  The anchor is one bolt with chain and a pin with some webbing and rap rings.
content.location: Two or three minutes farther right past Second Choice.  The route starts up on a ledge and there are two other routes to the left that also start on the same ledge.

content.description:
This route has not seen much traffic, most likely because the guide book gives little information and says that it has a one-bolt anchor (looks like it from the ground but there are two bolts). With some more traffic this route will clean up nicely (except perhaps the big ledges near the end - lots of bird poop).

I really enjoyed the variety that it offered: hand jams, stemming, offwidth (or lie-back), little chimney (with 5" crack in the back) then some fun ridge moves to finish. Stellar.

A 70m rope will get you back to the ledge ~10 feet off the ground. Easy down climb.
content.protection: The first half takes a few BD 2's & 3's with one smaller piece in the start. From the good ledge the crack behind the flake starts 3" and quickly goes 4" and then 5". There is a two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: This route is right of the leaning pillar located where the approach trail meets the wall. Look for the twin crack start above a few feet of ledgy, easy climbing. The right crack arches to the left to meet the anchors. Climb the left crack once they diverge.

climbs.name: (Brutus of) Wyde Choice
climbs.fa: Patrick Kingsbury, Pamela Shanti Pack, Spring 2010.

content.description: An anti-classic of sorts, a squeeze chimney leading up to the top of an obvious pillar.
content.protection: Though finger size gear is available behind the flake, place at your own risk as it may topple the entire first half of the route. Rappel from two bolt anchor.
content.location: Located to the right of the trail towards "Critics Choice", up the right side of the obvious pillar.
